p: The same concepts have been extended to other organisms, including humans, and applied to the study of disease [ 20, 21, 22, 23]. In Mendelian disorders, for example, genes harbouring disease mutations with a dominant phenotype display significantly higher network connectivity than genes with a recessive phenotype [ 23, 24], and cancer driver genes tend to be centrally located in protein–protein interaction networks [ 22]. These observations give important indications for genes’ function prediction and for the prioritisation of therapeutic targets [ 25, 26].
